verses.text: Dionysius, bishop of Alexandria, as presbyter had charge of the catechetical school under Heraclas, and was the most distinguished pupil of Origen.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 69:3
verses.text: Consenting to the doctrine of Cyprian and the African synod, on the rebaptizing of heretics, he sent many letters to different people, which are yet extant; He wrote one to Fabius, bishop of the church at Antioch, On penitence, another To the Romans, by the hand of Hippolytus, two letters To Xystus, who had succeeded Stephen, two also To Philemon and Dionysius, presbyters of the church at Rome, and another To the same Dionysius, afterwards bishop of Rome; and To Novatian, treating of their claim that Novatian had been ordained bishop of Rome, against his will.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 69:4
verses.text: The beginning of this epistle is as follows: "Dionysius to Novatian, his brother greeting.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 69:5
verses.text: If you have been ordained unwillingly, as you say, you will prove it, when you shall willingly retire".

verses.name: Life of Jerome 69:6
verses.text: There is another epistle of his also To Dionysius and Didymus, and many Festal epistles on the passover, written in a declamatory style, also one to the church of Alexandria On exile, one To Hierax,bishop in Egypt, and yet others On mortality, On the Sabbath, andOn the gymnasium, also one To Hermammon and others On the persecution of Decius, and two books Against Nepos the bishop, who asserted in his writings a thousand years reign in the body.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 69:7
verses.text: Among other things he diligently discussed the Apocalypse of John, and wrote Against Sabellius and To Ammon, bishop of Bernice, and To Telesphorus, also To Euphranor, also four books To Dionysius, bishop of Rome, to the Laodiceans On penitence, to Origen On martyrdom, to the Armenians On penitence,also On the order of transgression, to Timothy On nature, to Euphranor On temptation, many letters also To Basilides, in one of which he asserts that he also began to write commentaries on Ecclesiastes.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 69:8
verses.text: The notable epistle which he wrote against Paul of Samosata, a few days before his death is also current.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 69:9
verses.text: He died in the twelfth year of Gallienus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 70:1
verses.text: Chapter LXX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 70:2
verses.text: Novatianus, presbyter of Rome, attempted to usurp the sacerdotal chair occupied by Cornelius, and established the dogma of the Novatians, or as they are called in Greek, the Cathari, by refusing to receive penitent apostates.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 70:3
verses.text: Novatus, author ofthis doctrine, was a presbyter of Cyprian.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 70:4
verses.text: He wrote, On the passover, On the Sabbath, On circumcision, On the priesthood, On prayer,On the food of the Jews, On zeal, On Attalus, and many others, especially, a great volume On the Trinity, a sort of epitome of the work of Tertullian, which many mistakenly ascribe to Cyprian.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 71:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 71:2
verses.text: Malchion, the highly gifted presbyter of the church at Antioch, who had most successfully taught rhetoric in the same city, held a discussion with Paul of Samosata, who as bishop of the church at Antioch, had introduced the doctrine of Artemon, and this was taken down by short hand writers.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 71:3
verses.text: This dialogue is still extant, and yet another extended epistle written by him, in behalf of the council, is addressed to Dionysius and Maximus, bishops of Rome and Alexandria.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 71:4
verses.text: He flourished under Claudius and Aurelianus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 72:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 72:2
verses.text: Archelaus, bishop of Mesopotamia, composed in the Syriac language, a book of the discussion which he held with Manichaeus, when he came from Persia.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 72:3
verses.text: This book, which is translated into Greek, is possessed by many.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 72:4
verses.text: He flourished under the Emperor Probus, who succeeded Aurelianus and Tacitus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 73:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 73:2
verses.text: Anatolius of Alexandria, bishop of Laodicea in Syria, who flourished under the emperors Probus and Carus, was a man of wonderful learning in arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, grammar, rhetoric, and dialectic.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 73:3
verses.text: We can get an idea of the greatness of his genius from the volume which he wrote On the passover and his ten books On the institutes of arithmetic.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 74:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXIV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 74:2
verses.text: Victorinus, bishop of Pettau, was not equally familiar with Latin and Greek.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 74:3
verses.text: On this account his works though noble in thought, are inferior in style.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 74:4
verses.text: They are the following: Commentaries On Genesis, On Exodus, On Leviticus, On Isaiah, On Ezekiel, On Habakkuk, On Ecclesiastes, On the Song of Songs, On the Apocalypse of John, Against all heresies and many others.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 74:5
verses.text: At the last he received the crown of martyrdom.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 75:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 75:2
verses.text: Pamphilus the presbyter, patron of Eusebius bishop of Caesarea, was so inflamed with love of sacred literature, that he transcribed the greater part of the works of Origen with his own hand and these are still preserved in the library at Caesarea.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 75:3
verses.text: I have twenty-five volumes of Commentaries of Origen, written in his hand, On the twelve prophets which I hug and guard with such joy, that I deem myself to have the wealth of Croesus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 75:4
verses.text: And if it is such joy to have one epistle of a martyr how much more to have so many thousand lines which seem to me to be traced in his blood.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 75:5
verses.text: He wrote an Apology for Origen before Eusebius had written his and was put to death at Caesarea in Palestine in the persecution of Maximinus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 76:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXVI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 76:2
verses.text: Pierius, presbyter of the church at Alexandria in the reign of Carus and Diocletian, at the time when Theonas ruled as bishop in the same church, taught the people with great success and attained such elegance of language and published so many treatises on all sorts of subjects (which are still extant) that he was called Origen Junior.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 76:3
verses.text: He was remarkable for his self-discipline, devoted to voluntary poverty, and thoroughly acquainted with the dialectic art.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 76:4
verses.text: After the persecution, he passed the rest of his life at Rome.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 76:5
verses.text: There is extant a long treatise of his On the prophet Hosea which from internal evidence appears to have been delivered on the vigil of Passover.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 77:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXVII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 77:2
verses.text: Lucianus, a man of great talent, presbyter of the church at Antioch, was so diligent in the study of the Scriptures, that even now certain copies of the Scriptures bear the name of Lucian.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 77:3
verses.text: Works of his, On faith, and short Epistles to various people are extant.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 77:4
verses.text: He was put to death at Nicomedia for his confession of Christ in the persecution of Maximinus, and was buried at Helenopolis in Bithynia.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 78:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXVIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 78:2
verses.text: Phileas a resident of that Egyptian city which is called Thmuis, of noble family, and no small wealth, having become bishop, composed a finely written work in praise of martyrs and arguing against the judge who tried to compel him to offer sacrifices, was beheaded for Christ during the same persecution in which Lucianus was put to death at Nicomedia.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 79:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXIX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 79:2
verses.text: Arnobius was a most successful teacher of rhetoric at Sicca in Africa during the reign of Diocletian, and wrote volumes Against the nations which may be found everywhere.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 80:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 80:2
verses.text: Firmianus, known also as Lactantius, a disciple of Arnobius, during the reign of Diocletian summoned to Nicomedia with Flavius the Grammarian whose poem On medicine is still extant, taught rhetoric there and on account of his lack of pupils (since it was a Greek city) he betook himself to writing.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 80:3
verses.text: We have a Banquet of his which he wrote as a young man in Africa and an Itinerary of a journey from Africa to Nicomedia written in hexameters, and another book which is called The Grammarian and a most beautiful one On the wrath of God, and Divine institutes against the nations, seven books, and an Epitome of the same work in one volume, without a title, also two books To Asclepiades, one book On persecution, four books of Epistles to Probus, two books of Epistles to Severus, two books of Epistles to his pupil Demetrius and one book to the same On the work of God or the creation of man.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 80:4
verses.text: In his extreme old age he was tutor to Crispus Caesar a son of Constantine in Gaul, the same one who was afterwards put to death by his father.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 81:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 81:2
verses.text: Eusebius bishop of Caesarea in Palestine was diligent in the study of Divine Scriptures and with Pamphilus the martyr a most diligent investigator of the Holy Bible.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 81:3
verses.text: He published a great number of volumes among which are the following: Demonstrations of the Gospel twenty books, Preparations for the Gospel fifteen books, Theophanyfive books, Church history ten books, Chronicle of Universal history and an Epitome of this last.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 81:4
verses.text: Also On discrepancies between the Gospels, On Isaiah, ten books, also Against Porphyry, who was writing at that same time in Sicily as some think, twenty-five books, also one book of Topics, six books of Apology for Origen, three books On the life of Pamphilus, other brief works On the martyrs, exceedingly learned Commentaries on one hundred and fifty Psalms, and many others.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 81:5
verses.text: He flourished chiefly in the reigns of Constantine the Great and Constantius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 81:6
verses.text: His surname Pamphilus arose from his friendship for Pamphilus the martyr.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 82:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 82:2
verses.text: Reticius bishop of Autun, among the Aedui, had a great reputation in Gaul in the reign of Constantine.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 82:3
verses.text: I have read his commentaries On the Song of Songs and another great volume Against Novatian but besides these, I have found no works of his.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 83:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 83:2
verses.text: Methodius, bishop of Olympus in Lycia and afterwards of Tyre, composed books Against Porphyry written in polished and logical style also a Banquet of the ten virgins, an excellent work On the resurrection, against Origen and On the Pythonissa and On free will, also against Origen.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 83:3
verses.text: He also wrote commentaries On Genesis and On the Song of Songs and many others which are widely read.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 83:4
verses.text: At the end of the recent persecution or, as others affirm, in the reign of Decius and Valerianus, he was crowned with martyrdom at Chalcis in Greece.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 84:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXIV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 84:2
verses.text: Juvencus, a Spaniard of noble family and presbyter, translating the four gospels almost verbally in hexameter verses, composed four books.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 84:3
verses.text: He wrote some other things in the same metre relating to the order of the sacraments.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 84:4
verses.text: He flourished in the reign of Constantinus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 85:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 85:2
verses.text: Eustathius, a Pamphilian from Side, bishop first of Beroea in Syria and then of Antioch, ruled the church and, composing many things against the doctrine of the Arians, was driven into exile under the emperor Constantius into Trajanopolis in Thrace where he is until this day.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 85:3
verses.text: Works of his are extant On the soul, On ventriloquism Against Origen and Letters too numerous to mention.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 86:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXVI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 86:2
verses.text: Marcellus, bishop of Ancyra, flourished in the reign of Constantinus and Constantius and wrote many volumes of various Propositions and especially against the Arians.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 86:3
verses.text: Works of Asterius and Apollinarius against him are current, which accuse him of Sabellianism.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 86:4
verses.text: Hilary too, in the seventh book of his work Against the Arians, mentions him as a heretic, but he defends himself against the charge through the fact that Julius and Athanasius bishops of Rome and Alexandria communed with him.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 87:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXVII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 87:2
verses.text: Athanasius bishop of Alexandria, hard pressed by the wiles of the Arians, fled to Constans emperor of Gaul.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 87:3
verses.text: Returning thence with letters and, after the death of the emperor, again taking refuge in flight, he kept in hiding until the accession of Jovian, when he returned to the church and died in the reign of Valens.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 87:4
verses.text: Various works by him are in circulation; two books Against the nations, one Against Valens and Ursacius, On virginity, very many On the persecutions of the Arians, also On the titles of the Psalms and Life of Anthony the monk, also Festal epistles and other works too numerous to mention.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 88:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 88:2
verses.text: Anthony the monk, whose life Athanasius bishop of Alexandria wrote a long work upon, sent seven letters in Coptic to various monasteries, letters truly apostolic in idea and language, and which have been translated into Greek.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 88:3
verses.text: The chief of these is To the Arsenoites.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 88:4
verses.text: He flourished during the reign of Constantinus and his sons.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 89:1
verses.text: Chapter LXXXIX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 89:2
verses.text: Basil bishop of Ancyra, [a doctor of] medicine, wrote a book Against Marcellus and on virginity and some other things—and in the reign of Constantius was, with Eustathius of Sebaste, primate of Macedonia.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 90:1
verses.text: Chapter XC.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 90:2
verses.text: Theodorus, bishop of Heraclea in Thrace, published in the reign of the emperor Constantius commentaries On Matthew and John, On the Epistles and On the Psalter.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 90:3
verses.text: These are written in a polished and clear style and show an excellent historical sense.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 91:1
verses.text: Chapter XCVI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 91:2
verses.text: Eusebius, a native of Sardinia, at first a lector at Rome and afterwards bishop of Vercelli, sent by the emperor Constantius to Scythopolis, and afterwards to Cappadocia, on account of his confession of the faith, returned to the church under the emperor Julian and published the Commentaries of Eusebius of Caesarea on the Psalms, which he had translated from Greek into Latin, and died during the reign of Valentian and Valens.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 92:1
verses.text: Chapter XCII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 92:2
verses.text: Triphylius, bishop of Ledra or Leucotheon, in Cyprus, was the most eloquent man of his age, and was distinguished during the reign of Constantius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 92:3
verses.text: I have read his Commentary on the Song of Songs.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 92:4
verses.text: He is said to have written many other works, none of which have come to our hand.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 93:1
verses.text: Chapter XCIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 93:2
verses.text: Donatus, from whom the Donatians arose in Africa in the reigns of the emperors Constantinus and Constantius, asserted that the scriptures were given up to the heathen by the orthodox during the persecution, and deceived almost all Africa, and especially Numidia by his persuasiveness.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 93:3
verses.text: Many of his works, which relate to his heresy, are extant, including On the Holy Spirit, a work which is Arian in doctrine.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 94:1
verses.text: Chapter XCIV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 94:2
verses.text: Asterius, a philosopher of the Arian party, wrote, during the reign of Constantius, commentaries On the Epistle to the Romans, On the Gospels and On the Psalms, also many other works which are diligently read by those of his party.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 95:1
verses.text: Chapter XCV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 95:2
verses.text: Lucifer, bishop of Cagliari, was sent by Liberius the bishop, with Pancratius and Hilary, clergy of the Roman church, to the emperor Constantius, as legates for the faith.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 95:3
verses.text: When he would not condemn the Nicene faith as represented by Athanasius, sent again to Palestine, with wonderful constancy and willingness to meet martyrdom, he wrote a book against the emperor Constantius and sent it to be read by him, and not long after he returned to Cagliari in the reign of the emperor Julian and died in the reign of Valentinian.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 96:1
verses.text: Chapter XCVII  Fortunatianus, an African by birth, bishop of Aquilia during the reign of Constantius, composed brief Commentaries on the gospels arranged by chapters, written in a rustic style, and is held in detestation because, when Liberius bishop of Rome was driven into exile for the faith, he was induced by the urgency of Fortunatianus to subscribe to heresy.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 97:1
verses.text: Chapter XCVIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 97:2
verses.text: Acacius, who, because he was blind in one eye, they nicknamed "the one-eyed," bishop of the church of Caesarea in Palestine, wrote seventeen volumes On Ecclesiastes and six of Miscellaneous questions, and many treatises besides on various subjects.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 97:3
verses.text: He was so influential in the reign of the emperor Constantius that he made Felix bishop of Rome in the place of Liberius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 98:1
verses.text: Chapter C.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 98:2
verses.text: Hilary, a bishop of Poitiers in Aquitania, was a member of the party of Saturninus bishop of Arles.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 98:3
verses.text: Banished into Phrygia by the Synod of Beziérs he composed twelve books Against the Arians and another book On Councils written to the Gallican bishops, and Commentaries on the Psalms that is on the first and second, from the fifty-first to the sixty-second, and from the one hundred and eighteenth to the end of the book.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 98:4
verses.text: In this work he imitated Origen, but added also some original matter.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 98:5
verses.text: There is a little book of his To Constantius which he presented to the emperor while he was living in Constantinople, and another On Constantius which he wrote after his death and a book Against Valens and Ursacius, containing a history of the Ariminian and Selucian Councils and To Sallust the prefect orAgainst Dioscurus, also a book of Hymns and mysteries, a commentary On Matthew and treatises On Job, which he translated freely from the Greek of Origen, and another elegant little work Against Auxentius andEpistles to different persons.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 98:6
verses.text: They say he has written On the Song of Songs but this work is not known to us.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 98:7
verses.text: He died at Poictiers during the reign of Valentinianus and Valens.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 99:1
verses.text: Chapter CI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 99:2
verses.text: Victorinus, an African by birth, taught rhetoric at Rome under the emperor Constantius and in extreme old age, yielding himself to faith in Christ wrote books against Arius, written in dialectic style and very obscure language, books which can only be understood by the learned.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 99:3
verses.text: He also wrote Commentaries on the Epistles.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 100:1
verses.text: Chapter CII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 100:2
verses.text: Titus bishop of Bostra, in the reign of the emperors Julian and Jovinian wrote vigorous works against the Manichaeans and some other things.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 100:3
verses.text: He died under Valens.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 100:4
verses.text: Damasus, bishop of Rome, had a fine talent for making verses and published many brief works in heroic metre.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 100:5
verses.text: He died in the reign of the Emperor Theodosius at the age of almost eighty.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 101:1
verses.text: Chapter CIV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 101:2
verses.text: Apollinarus, bishop of Laodicea, in Syria, the son of a presbyter, applied himself in his youth to the diligent study of grammar, and afterwards, writing innumerable volumes on the Holy Scriptures, died in the reign of the Emperor Theodosius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 101:3
verses.text: There are extant thirty books by him Against Porphyry, which are generally considered as among the best of his works.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 102:1
verses.text: Chapter CV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 102:2
verses.text: Gregory, bishop of Elvira, in Baetica, writing even to extreme old age, composed various treatises in mediocre language, and an elegant work On Faith.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 102:3
verses.text: He is said to be still living.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 103:1
verses.text: Chapter CVI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 103:2
verses.text: Pacianus, bishop of Barcelona, in the Pyrenees Mountains, a man of chaste eloquence, and as distinguished by his life as by his speech, wrote various short works, among which are The Deer, and Against the Novatians, and died in the reign of Emperor Theodosian, in extreme old age.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 104:1
verses.text: Chapter CVII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 104:2
verses.text: Photinus, of Gallograecia, a disciple of Marcellus, and ordained bishop of Sirmium, attempted to introduce the Ebionite heresy, and afterwards having been expelled from the church by the Emperor Valentinianus, wrote many volumes, among which the most distinguished are Against the nations, and To Valentinianus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 105:1
verses.text: Chapter CVIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 105:2
verses.text: Phoebadius, bishop of Agen, in Gaul, published a book Against the Arians.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 105:3
verses.text: There are said to be other works by him, which I have not yet read.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 105:4
verses.text: He is still living, infirm with age.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 106:1
verses.text: Chapter CIX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 106:2
verses.text: Didymus, of Alexandria, becoming blind while very young, and therefore ignorant of the rudiments of learning, displayed such a miracle of intelligence as to learn perfectly dialectics and even geometry, sciences which especially require sight.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 106:3
verses.text: He wrote many admirable works: Commentaries on all the Psalms, Commentaries on the Gospels of Matthew and John, On the doctrines, also two books Against the Arians, and one book On the Holy Spirit, which I translated in Latin, eighteen volumes On Isaiah, three books of commentaries On Hosea, addressed to me, and five books On Zechariah, written at my request, also commentaries On Job, and many other things, to give an account of which would be a work of itself.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 106:4
verses.text: He is still living, and has already passed his eighty-third year.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 107:1
verses.text: Chapter CX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 107:2
verses.text: Optatus the African, bishop of Milevis, during the reign of the Emperors Valentinianus and Valens, wrote in behalf of the Catholic party six books against the calumny of the Donatian party, in which he asserts that the crime of the Donatists is falsely charged upon the catholic party.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 108:1
verses.text: Chapter CXI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 108:2
verses.text: {{small-caps|Acilius Severus of Spain, of the family of that Severus to whom Lactantius' two books of Epistles are addressed, composed a volume of mingled poetry and prose which is a sort of guide book to his whole life.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 108:3
verses.text: This he called Calamity or Trial.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 108:4
verses.text: He died in the reign of Valentinianus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 109:1
verses.text: Chapter CXII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 109:2
verses.text: Cyril, bishop of Jerusalem often expelled by the church, and at last received, held the episcopate for eight consecutive years, in the reign of Theodosius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 109:3
verses.text: Certain Catachetical lectures of his, composed while he was a young man, are extant.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 110:1
verses.text: Chapter CXIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 110:2
verses.text: Euzoius, as a young man, together with Gregory, bishop of Nazianzan, was educated by Thespesius the rhetorician at Caesarea, and afterwards when bishop of the same city, with great pains attempted to restore the library, collected by Origen and Pamphilus, which had already suffered injury.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 110:3
verses.text: At last, in the reign of the Emperor Theodosian, he was expelled from the church.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 110:4
verses.text: Many and various treatises of his are in circulation, and one may easily become acquainted with them.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 111:1
verses.text: Chapter CXIV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 111:2
verses.text: Epiphanius, bishop of Salamina in Cyprus, wrote books Against all heresies and many others which are eagerly read by the learned, on account of their subject matter, and also by the plain people, on account of their language.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 111:3
verses.text: He is still living, and in his extreme old age composes various brief works.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 112:1
verses.text: Chapter CXV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 112:2
verses.text: Ephraim, deacon of the church at Edessa, composed many works in the Syriac language, and became so distinguished that his writings are repeated publicly in some churches, after the reading of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 112:3
verses.text: I once read in Greek a volume by him On the Holy Spirit, which some one had translated from the Syriac, and recognized even in translation, the incisive power of lofty genius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 112:4
verses.text: He died in the reign of Valens.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 113:1
verses.text: Chapter CXVI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 113:2
verses.text: Basil, bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia, the city formerly called Mazaca, composed admirable carefully written books Against Eunomius, a volume On the Holy Spirit, and nine homilies On the six days of creation, also a work On asceticism and short treatises on various subjects.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 113:3
verses.text: He died in the reign of Gratianus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 114:1
verses.text: Chapter CXVII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 114:2
verses.text: Gregory, bishop of Nazianzen, a most eloquent man, and my instructor in the Scriptures, composed works, amounting in all to thirty thousand lines, among which are On the death of his brother Caesarius, On charity, In praise of the Maccabees, In praise of Cyprian, In praise of Athanasius, In praise of Maximus the philosopher after he had returned from exile.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 114:3
verses.text: This latter however, some superscribe with the pseudonym of Herona, since there is another work by Gregory, upbraiding this same Maximus, as if one might not praise and upbraid the same person at one time or another as the occasion may demand.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 114:4
verses.text: Other works of his are a book in hexameter, containing, A discussion between virginity and marriage, two books Against Eunomius, one book On the Holy Spirit, and one Against the Emperor Julian.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 114:5
verses.text: He was a follower of Polemon in his style of speaking.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 114:6
verses.text: Having ordained his successor in the bishopric, during his own life time, he retired to the country where he lived the life of a monk and died, three years or more ago, in the reign of Theodosius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 115:1
verses.text: Chapter CXVIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 115:2
verses.text: Lucius, bishop of the Arian party after Athanasius, held the bishopric of the church at Alexandria, until the time of the Emperor Theodosius, by whom he was deposed.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 115:3
verses.text: Certain festal epistles of his, On the passover are extant, and a few short works of Miscellaneous propositions.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 116:1
verses.text: Chapter CXIX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 116:2
verses.text: Diodorus, bishop of Tarsus enjoyed a great reputation while he was still presbyter of Antioch.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 116:3
verses.text: Commentaries of his On the epistles are extant, as well as many other works in the manner of Eusebius the great of Emesa, whose meaning he has followed, but whose eloquence he could not imitate on account of his ignorance of secular literature.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 117:1
verses.text: Chapter CXX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 117:2
verses.text: Eunomius, bishop of Cyzicus and member of the Arian party, fell into such open blasphemy in his heresy, as to proclaim publicly what the others concealed.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 117:3
verses.text: He is said to be still living in Cappadocia, and to write much against the church.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 117:4
verses.text: Replies to him have been made by Apollinarius, Didymus, Basil of Caesarea, Gregory Nazianzen, and Gregory of Nyssa.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 118:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 118:2
verses.text: Priscillianus, bishop of Abila, belonged to the party of Hydatius and Ithacius, and was put to death at Trèves by the tyrant Maximus.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 118:3
verses.text: He published many short writings, some of which have reached us.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 118:4
verses.text: He is still accused by some, of being tainted with Gnosticism, that is, with the heresy of Basilides or Mark, of whom Irenaeus writes, while his defenders maintain that he was not at all of this way of thinking.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 119:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 119:2
verses.text: Latronianus, of Spain, a man of great learning, and in the matter of versification worthy to be compared with the poets of ancient time, was also put to death at Trèves with Priscillianus, Felicissimus, Julianus, and Euchrotia, coöriginators with him of schism.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 119:3
verses.text: Various fruits of his genius written in different metres are extant.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 120:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 120:2
verses.text: Tiberianus, the Baetican, in answer to an insinuation that he shared the heresy of Priscillian, wrote an apology in pompous and mongrel language.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 120:3
verses.text: But after the death of his friends, overcome by the tediousness of exile, he changed his mind, as it is written in Holy Scripture "the dog returned to his vomit," and married a nun, a virgin dedicated to Christ.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 121:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXIV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 121:2
verses.text: Ambrose a bishop of Milan, at the present time is still writing.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 121:3
verses.text: I withhold my judgment of him, because he is still alive, fearing either to praise or blame lest in the one event, I should be blamed for adulation, and in the other for speaking the truth.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 122:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 122:2
verses.text: Evagrius, bishop of Antioch, a man of remarkably keen mind, while he was yet presbyter read me various treatises on various topics, which he had not yet published.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 122:3
verses.text: He translated also the Life of the blessed Anthony from the Greek of Athanasius into our language.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 123:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXVI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 123:2
verses.text: Ambrose of Alexandria, pupil of Didymus, wrote a long work On doctrines against Apollinaris, and as some one has lately informed me, Commentaries on Job.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 123:3
verses.text: He is still living.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 124:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXVII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 124:2
verses.text: Maximus the philosopher, born at Alexandria, ordained bishop at Constantinople and deposed, wrote a remarkable work On faith against the Arians and gave it to the Emperor Gratianus, at Milan.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 125:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXVIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 125:2
verses.text: Gregory bishop of Nyssa, the brother of Basil of Caesarea, a few years since read to Gregory Nazianzan and myself a work against Eunomius.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 125:3
verses.text: He is said to have also written many other works, and to be still writing.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 126:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXIX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 126:2
verses.text: John, presbyter of the church at Antioch, a follower of Eusebius of Emesa and Diodorus, is said to have composed many books, but of these I have only read his On the priesthood.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 127:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXX.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 127:2
verses.text: Gelasius, bishop of Caesarea in Palestine after Euzoius, is said to write more or less in carefully polished style, but not to publish his works.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 128:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXXI.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 128:2
verses.text: Theotimus, bishop of Tomi, in Scythia, has published brief and epigrammatical treatises, in the form of dialogues, and in olden style.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 128:3
verses.text: I hear that he is now writing other works.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 129:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXXII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 129:2
verses.text: Dexter, son of Pacianus whom I mentioned above, distinguished in his generation and devoted to the Christian faith, has, I am told, written a Universal History, which I have not yet read.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 130:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXXIII.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 130:2
verses.text: Amphilochius, bishop of Iconium, recently read to me a book On the Holy Spirit, arguing that He is God, that He is to be worshipped, and that He is omnipotent.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 131:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXXIV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 131:2
verses.text: Sophronius, a man of superlative learning, wrote while yet a lad, In praise of Bethlehem and recently a notable volume, On the overthrow of Serapis, and also to Eustachius, On virginity, and a Life of Hilarion the monk.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 131:3
verses.text: He rendered short works of mine into Greek in a very finished style, the Psalter also, and the Prophets, which I translated from Hebrew into Latin.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 132:1
verses.text: Chapter CXXXV.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 132:2
verses.text: I, Jerome, son of Eusebius, of the city of Strido, which is on the border of Dalmatia and Pannonia and was overthrown by the Goths, up to the present year, that is, the fourteenth of the Emperor Theodosius, have written the following: Life of Paul the monk, one book of Letters to different persons, an Exhortation to Heliodorus, Controversy of Luciferianus and Orthodoxus, Chronicle of universal history, 28 homilies of Origen on Jeremiah and Ezekiel, which I translated from Greek into Latin, On the Seraphim, On Osanna, On the prudent and the prodigal sons, On three questions of the ancient law, Homilies on the Song of Songs two, Against Helvidius, On the perpetual virginity of Mary, To Eustochius, On maintaining virginity, one book of Epistles to Marcella, a consolatory letter to Paula On the death of a daughter, three books of Commentaries on the epistle of Paul to the Galatians, likewise three books of Commentaries on the epistle to the Ephesians, On the epistle to Titus one book, On the epistle to Philemon one, Commentaries on Ecclesiastes, one book of Hebrew questions on Genesis, one book On places in Judea, one book of Hebrew names, Didymus on the Holy Spirit, which I translated into Latin one book, 39 homilies on LukeOn Psalms 10 to 16, seven books, On the captive Monk, The Life of the blessed Hilarion.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 132:3
verses.text: I translated the New Testament from the Greek, and the Old Testament from the Hebrew, and how many Letters I have written To Paula and Eustochius I do not know, for I write daily.

verses.name: Life of Jerome 132:4
verses.text: I wrote moreover, two books of Explanations on Micah, one book On Nahum, two books On Habakkuk, one On Zephaniah, one On Haggai, and many others On the prophets, which are not yet finished, and which I am still at work upon.
